import React from 'react'; import { Box, UnorderedList, ListItem, ModalBody, Image, Button, Link, HStack, useColorModeValue, Code, Heading, } from '@chakra-ui/react'; import { BsPlay, BsFileEarmarkCode, BsNewspaper } from 'react-icons/bs'; import Autocomplete from '../../images/autocomplete-web.png'; const Webapps = () => { const firstColor = useColorModeValue('red', 'yellow'); // const secondColor = useColorModeValue('teal', ) return (

Development Frameworks:
Design Frameworks:

Over Summer, I worked with professor{' '} Kevin Lin {' '} to develop more interactive webapps for text-based programming assessments. All of the take assignments for the introductory computer science series that we currently support have largely text-based specifications with low student interactivity. This paper goes into the process of connecting student written code to a simple front end interface that dynamically responds to user interactions. Since all of the front end visualizations are based on AMP and direct HTML, we have standarized templates for developing these apps. Instructors and students alike can run and modify these web apps on their own computers or deploy their apps online for access from any smart device at no cost. The tutorial presents examples from CS1 and CS2 courses in Python and Java, but the ideas apply generally. ); }; export default Webapps;
